hints_html:
Try multiplying the numerator and denominator by the denominator’s conjugate.

The conjugate of a binomial \(a + b\) is \(a - b\). Note that \((a+b)(a-b) = a^2 - b^2\).

sols_html:
Multiplying the numerator and denominator by \(\sqrt{1+2x} + 1\) yields:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{x}{\sqrt{1+2x} - 1} &= \lim_{x \to 0} \left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{1+2x} - 1} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{1+2x} + 1}{\sqrt{1+2x} + 1}\right) \\ &= \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{x(\sqrt{1+2x} + 1)}{(\sqrt{1+2x})^2 - 1^2} \\ &= \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{x(\sqrt{1+2x} + 1)}{(1+2x) - 1} \\ &= \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sqrt{1+2x} + 1}{2} \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{1+2\cdot0} + 1}{2} \\ &= {\color{blue} 1}\end{aligned}\]
